title: React Basics
description: Test your knowledge of React fundamentals

questions.question: What is React?
options: A JavaScript library for building user interfaces
questions.explanation: React is a JavaScript library developed by Facebook for building user interfaces with reusable components.

questions.question: What are React Hooks?
options: Functions that let you use state in functional components
questions.explanation: Hooks are functions that let you 'hook into' React state and lifecycle features from functional components.

questions.question: Which hook is used for side effects in React?
questions.explanation: useEffect is the Hook for performing side effects in functional components, like data fetching and subscriptions.

questions.question: What does JSX stand for?
questions.explanation: JSX stands for JavaScript XML, allowing you to write HTML-like code in JavaScript.

questions.question: In React, what is a component?
questions.explanation: A component is a reusable piece of UI that can accept props and manage state independently.

questions.question: What is the purpose of ReactDOM.render()?
options: To render React elements to the DOM
questions.explanation: ReactDOM.render() is used to render React elements into the DOM.

questions.question: What is a state in React?
questions.explanation: State is managed within the component and can change.

questions.question: What is the virtual DOM?
options: A programming concept where an ideal, or 'virtual', representation of a UI is kept in memory
questions.explanation: Virtual DOM is a lightweight copy of the real DOM for efficient updates.

questions.question: What is a prop in React?
What is the use of keys in React?
options: To identify unique elements in lists
questions.explanation: Keys help React identify which items have changed in lists.

title: JavaScript Advanced
description: Challenge yourself with advanced JavaScript concepts

questions.question: What is async/await?
questions.explanation: Async/await is syntactic sugar for working with Promises, making asynchronous code look more like synchronous code.

questions.question: What does 'this' refer to in JavaScript?
options: The object that owns the method
questions.explanation: 'this' refers to the object that owns the method being called, and its value depends on how the function is invoked.

questions.question: What is closure in JavaScript?
options: A way to close a function
A function that has access to variables from its outer scope
questions.explanation: A closure is a function that has access to variables from its outer (enclosing) scope, even after the outer function has returned.

questions.question: What is destructuring?
options: Extracting values from objects or arrays into distinct variables
questions.explanation: Destructuring is a convenient way of extracting multiple values from objects or arrays into distinct variables.

questions.question: What is the spread operator (...) used for?
questions.explanation: The spread operator allows an iterable to be expanded in places where zero or more elements are expected.

questions.question: What is hoisting in JavaScript?
questions.explanation: Hoisting is JavaScript's default behavior of moving declarations to the top.

questions.question: What is a Promise in JavaScript?
options: A value that may be available now or in the future
questions.explanation: A Promise is an object representing the eventual completion or failure of an asynchronous operation.

questions.question: What is event bubbling?
options: Events propagate from child to parent
Events propagate from parent to child
questions.explanation: In event bubbling, the event starts from the target element and bubbles up to the root.

questions.question: What is a module in JavaScript?
options: A way to organize code into reusable pieces
questions.explanation: Modules allow for better code organization and reuse.

questions.question: What is the purpose of 'strict mode'?
options: To make JavaScript stricter and catch common coding errors
questions.explanation: Strict mode helps catch errors early.

title: Web Security
description: Learn about web security best practices

questions.question: What is CSRF?
questions.explanation: CSRF is an attack that tricks users into performing unwanted actions on websites where they're authenticated.

questions.question: What does XSS stand for?
questions.explanation: XSS (Cross-Site Scripting) is a vulnerability that allows attackers to inject malicious scripts into web pages.

questions.question: Which is NOT a best practice for password security?
options: Hash passwords using a strong algorithm
questions.explanation: Storing passwords in plain text is a critical security vulnerability. Passwords should always be hashed and salted.

questions.question: What is HTTPS?
questions.explanation: HTTPS is the secure version of HTTP that encrypts data in transit using SSL/TLS protocols.

questions.question: What is SQL Injection?
options: Inserting malicious SQL code into input fields
questions.explanation: SQL Injection is an attack where malicious SQL code is inserted through input fields to manipulate databases.

questions.question: What is OWASP?
questions.explanation: OWASP is a non-profit organization that works to improve software security.

questions.question: What is a firewall?
questions.explanation: A firewall monitors and controls incoming and outgoing network traffic.

questions.question: What is two-factor authentication?
options: Something you know and something you have
questions.explanation: 2FA adds an extra layer of security.

questions.question: What is a vulnerability?
questions.explanation: Vulnerabilities can be exploited by threats.

title: Mobile Development
description: Test your mobile development knowledge

questions.question: What is React Native?
options: A framework for building native mobile apps with JavaScript
questions.explanation: React Native is a framework that allows developers to build native iOS and Android apps using JavaScript and React.

questions.question: What is Expo?
options: A framework that simplifies React Native development
questions.explanation: Expo is a framework and platform that makes it easy to build, deploy, and iterate on native iOS, Android, and web apps.

questions.question: Which of these is a mobile OS?
questions.explanation: iOS is the mobile operating system developed by Apple for iPhone and iPad devices.

questions.question: What is Flutter?
options: A Google framework for building mobile apps with Dart
questions.explanation: Flutter is an open-source UI framework by Google for building mobile applications using the Dart programming language.

questions.question: What is a responsive design?
options: Design that adapts to different screen sizes
questions.explanation: Responsive design is an approach that makes web applications work well on devices of various sizes and orientations.

questions.question: What is Android?
questions.explanation: Android is a mobile operating system developed by Google.

questions.question: What is Swift?
questions.explanation: Swift is Apple's programming language for iOS development.

questions.question: What is Kotlin?
questions.explanation: Kotlin is a modern programming language for Android apps.

questions.question: What is hybrid app development?
options: Using web tech for native apps
questions.explanation: Hybrid apps use web technologies wrapped in native containers.

questions.question: What is PWA?
questions.explanation: PWAs are web apps that can work offline and feel like native apps.

title: Advanced React
description: Test your knowledge of advanced React concepts

questions.question: What is React Fiber?
questions.explanation: Fiber is the new reconciliation engine in React 16+.

questions.question: What is Suspense in React?
options: For code splitting and lazy loading
questions.explanation: Suspense lets components 'wait' for something before rendering.

questions.question: What is a higher-order component?
options: A function that takes a component and returns a new one
questions.explanation: HOCs are used for reusing component logic.

questions.question: What is the purpose of shouldComponentUpdate?
options: To optimize performance by preventing unnecessary renders
questions.explanation: It determines if a component should re-render.

questions.question: What is a reducer in Redux?
options: A function that takes state and action and returns new state

questions.question: What is middleware in Redux?
questions.explanation: Middleware is used for logging, async logic, etc.

questions.question: What is React Context?
options: A way to pass data through the component tree without props
questions.explanation: Context provides global data without prop drilling.

title: Frontend Performance Optimization
description: Test your knowledge of optimizing frontend performance

questions.question: What is critical rendering path?
options: The sequence of steps the browser goes through to render a page

questions.question: What is lazy loading?
questions.explanation: Lazy loading defers loading of non-critical resources.

questions.question: What is code splitting?
questions.explanation: Code splitting improves initial load times.

questions.question: What is prefetching?
options: Loading resources before they are needed

questions.question: What is Web Vitals?
questions.explanation: Web Vitals measure loading, interactivity, stability.

title: Node.js Basics
description: Test your knowledge of Node.js fundamentals

questions.question: What is Node.js?
options: A JavaScript runtime built on Chrome's V8 engine
questions.explanation: Node.js allows running JavaScript on the server.

questions.question: What is npm?
questions.explanation: npm is used to manage packages for Node.js.

questions.question: What is event-driven programming in Node.js?
questions.explanation: Node.js uses an event loop for non-blocking I/O.

questions.question: What is a module in Node.js?
What is callback hell?
questions.explanation: Nested callbacks make code hard to read.

title: Microservices Architecture
description: Test your knowledge of microservices

questions.question: What is API Gateway in microservices?
options: A single entry point for clients

questions.question: What is sidecar pattern?
options: Deploys helper components with main app

questions.question: What is phishing?
options: Fraudulent attempt to obtain sensitive info

questions.question: What is differential privacy?
options: Adds noise to protect individual data

questions.explanation: SQL is used to communicate with databases.

questions.question: What is JOIN?
options: To combine rows from two tables

questions.question: What is LEFT JOIN?
options: All from left, matching from right
